content.description: Maybe the first and only trad route at Med Wall!  Probably more of a boulder problem.  That being said, be very careful placing pro in limestone, placements can/may be weak.  No bolts, no anchor on this one.  Climb the corner to the top, can wrap a tree or large boulder for top rope anchor or walk off.
content.protection: no bolts, no anchor, can use natural anchor with a few trees or tie off a top boulder.  Takes .75-2’s
content.location: Far left side of med wall, near the approach trail that goes to the top.  I normally go to Buda Belly, then take the lower trail in all the tall grass left, then you will see a little slab/rock scramble (the blue "approach" line in Matt's petri dish topos).  This will take you to a ledge.  Head hard left either up more rock scrambling to next ledge or through some cedar trees and one will find the crack.

climbs.name: Salute the Colonel
climbs.fa: FLA:Matt Markell 3MAR2021  Old chopped TR Bolts on top but unknown if this far right line was done.

content.description: Start off the ground or on the upper ledge system of Petri (belay bolt available).  From the ground, surmount the easy, stepped ledges past two bolts onto the upper slab.  Skip the belay bolt if leading from the ground and continue up onto the main headwall.  Climb through the most featured section vertical of rock below the dull Arete to reach the headwall.  Pull onto the steeper upper section and climb the remaining arete.  As you near the top, trend left of the edge to finish on at the anchor on the left face.  When lowering you will end up on the left side of the trees a bit away from your partner.
content.protection: Glue In Bolts, Steel Lower Off
content.location: Continue left below the Ketosis Bulge on Buda Belly to a series of stepped ledges 4-5' in height.  COL goes up just right of the medium sized oak tree.

climbs.name: Citation Needed
climbs.fa: Old Chopped TR Unknown - Bolted by Matt Markell FEB2021

content.description: Begins at a belay bolt on a small ledge directly above the approach gulley.  Climb up the slabs below an obvious, small left facing flake.  Climb the face up towards the flake and continue up the flake until it thins out.  Final moves up and slightly left on featured rock gets you to the anchor.  If only this were 30m!!
content.protection: Glue In Bolts, Lower Off Anchor
content.location: Continue East (climbers left) past the Ketosis bulge on Buda and take a right fork up into the woods.  A series of low angle slabs will appear in 25' with a stepped gulley above.  Either begin climbing from here up the 3rd class ledges (one bolt if you want it) to the upper slabs or scramble up to the starting ledge (belay bolt provided).

climbs.name: Add My Name to the Paper
climbs.fa: Unknown old chopped TR.  Bolted FEB2021 - Matt Markell

content.description: Start near a belay bolt just right of the small cedar tree.  Scramble up the slab and start climbing the steeper rock just left of the groove.  Holds become scarce as you make your way up the wall towards the prominent right slanting crack above.  Pull the crux and the cruise large holds up and right along the crack to the anchor.
content.protection: Glue In Bolts, Lower Off Anchor
content.location: Just right of a small cedar tree on the sloping mid-hight ledge.

content.description: This is the first band of rock that makes up the leftmost section of Med Wall proper. It begins just right of the upper approach trail and gradually grows in height until meeting up with Buda Belly Wall at a left facing corner left of the Ketosis bulge. All of the climbing takes place off of a mid-height ledge system. The lower bands are lower angle and not very technical in nature. The upper rock is high quality and EXTREMELY featured with plentiful pockets on bullet, dark grey rock. As with much of Med Wall, one wishes it were longer! Most climbs here will be 3-4 bolts max. A good section to bang out a lot of moderates quickly if other areas are crowded.
